Award.AwardTitle: IEEE Communications Society Conference on Sensor, Mesh, and Ad Hoc Communications and Networks (SECON) 2012: Student Travel Awards

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports students to attend the Ninth Annual IEEE Communications Society
Conference on Sensor, Mesh, and Ad Hoc Communications and Networks (SECON 2012) to be
held in Seoul, South Korea in June 2012. SECON is a premier conference in the areas of sensor, ad
hoc, and mesh networking, serving as a meeting point of researchers from academia and industry,
as well as practitioners in diverse fields of wireless communications and networking. This project
supports travel to the conference for US based graduate students who might not otherwise be able
to attend for financial reasons. Students will be exposed to the conference, a technical forum that
is critical for their professional maturity and development. Students will also be involved in various
activities and work as volunteers to support these activities, increasing their level of involvement
and connection to the conference and the research community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant provided travel funding for ten graduate students studying in the United States to attend the IEEE Communications Society Conference on Sensor, Mesh, and Ad Hoc Communications and Networks (SECON) 2012.  The IEEE SECON 2012 conference was held in Seoul, South Korea, during the month of June 2012, and details of the conference and program can be found online at http://www.ieee-secon.org/2012/.  Based on our intial efforts to solicit travel grant applications from students hoping to attend the conference either to present a paper, poster, or demo or to attend technical talks, we received 18 applications for travel support, and 11 of these applications were selected for support.  One of the awardees did not attend due to visa issues, so only 10 awards were ultimately granted.  Through this NSF grant, we were able to provide travel reimbursements to students to cover the costs of their airfare, hotel, and other travel expenses, approximately $1400 per travel grant awardee based on actual travel expenses incurred by the individual awardees.  The IEEE Communications Society provided funding for an additional three student travel grants.  The PI was solely responsible for soliciting travel grant applications from students, reviewing applications, selecting award recipients, and award administration.
